patches from Paez took the command of the town, and probably on Paez's arrival he will prevent blOodShed. But should he not, PaeZ has on the east Bermudez with many troops, on the south Meserez with 1900 men, and on the west Porto Cabello with the troops there opposed to him. The whole number of Paez's troops cannot be estimated at more than 5000, ,probably less. The citizens of Caracas and Venezuela are apparently opposed to all these meas ures, and are loudly crying for peace on any terms. The people in the interior know little and care less for the political state of the country. IfBolivar makes his appearance in Venezuek, doubtless all political troubles will be immediately qui- eted.-Mer. Ado.

 Extraordinary instance of natural qf- fectioh and fcrOcity of Cat.-The fol- lowing facts are we'll authenticated "A family in the Lower Town of Quebec, had cat with kittens about two months old one day the mistress of the house had occasion to open cupboard where provisions were kept, and on shutting it, a kitten got squeesed by the door, aud utter ed loud and piercing cry. The mis- tress of the house, after seeing it was dis engaged, apparently not much hurt, turn- ed to go to another part of the room. Presently the mother of the kitten came in, went up to it, and then flew furiously at the mistress of the house, first biting and scratching her legs and thighs and arms, and proceeding to her neck, upon which she fixed the woman used her hands to preserve her eyes, lowering her head to save her throat, her cries alarmed her hus- band, who came into the room to her as- sistance the cat then let go her hold, re- ceived kick, passed unde the stove to the other side of it, where she was followed by the man, she then repassed making again at the woman but being pursued she went out the door, which was immediately clos- cd. She then began to fly up against the door uttering hideous cries; the family was so much alarmed that assistance was had, and finally the cat was killed on entering the door, partially opened for the purpose. The woman was much hurt. but her wounds are nearly healed. The cat had frequent ly shown symptoms of boldness and feroci- ty, when irritated, but never before in a way to excite alarm in the family.

Shocking Transaction at NST-LOndOn. We learn from correspondent at New London, that on Monday night last, u quarrel took place in cellar, occupied as grocery, between a man by the name of Spencer, and two brothers by the name of Forsyth. Spencer was, or had been, sailor. After he left the cellar, the two Forsyths offered the fireman of the steam boat, Long Branch, who was present, three dollars if he would Ego and beat the d-d rascal" while they were to stand by with clubs, and knock the first man down who attempted to interfere The frman clo- sed with the proposal, followed Spencer, and knocked him down in the street. Af- ter some struggle, Spencer succeeded in getting to the Hole-n-the-Wal public house, though not until he had received a severe foging. The fireman afterwards went to Spencer, expressed his sorrow for what he had done, and by way of settle ment paid him the three dollars received from the Forsyth, and took his receipt in full for the Aoging. Spencer afterwards died, and on Saturday the fireman and two Forsyths were lodged in gaol to await their trial. The same day, Saturday the wife of Spencer, being somewhat intoxica- ted met Mrs Barns, who was no friend of hers. A quarrel ensued, severe blows were interchanged, and Mrs. went off severely pounded. Yesterday morning she died; and the deceased Spencer's widow was lodged in prison with those who had compassed tbn death of her husband-a!l to meet their trials together.

 The New England Farmer gives the following extracts from London, an Eng fish writer.

 An American laborer is most expert al the use of the axe and the scythe; the spade he handles in very awkward man. ner. and has no ideas of banking, hedging, clipping, or cutting hedges, and many oth- CT operations known to every laborer m a hiohlv cultivated and enclosed country like Britain. Rut the versatility ot talents of an American laborer amply compensatcS for his inexperieuce ill these operations, and is more useful in his circumstances In handling the saw, the hammer, and even the trowel, the British laborer has no chance with him. Most of them can build > a house, mend plough or wagon, and C. ven the harness, aud kill and dress sheep and pigs.

 As a country for British farmer to em- igrate to, we consider the United States as superior to every other, in many respects First on account of its form ofgovernment: by which property is secure, personal lib- erty greater than any where else, consist GnlV WlLn puDlIC SdIOlJ , "n~ Oo'' A"'AA'N"A" ed at less expence than under any govern ment in the world. Secondly, on account of the stock of people being generally British, and speaking the same language. The only objection we have to America is the climate, the long and severe winter, and the rapid and hot spring and summer. Equally good land, and nearly as cheap, may be had in the south of Russia and in Poland, as in America; but who that knows any thing of the governments of tIJose countries, or even of Germany and France, would voluntarily put themselves in their power while the United States are accessible Who would live in country of tyrsnnic nobles, often very deficient of moral principal and ofa peasantry little better than hogs, and not so we'll fed and lodged as that animal is in England Who would live in country of passports, of spies, and swarming with beggarly gentry!
English notiees of 1lnleriean Agrieultuce.

NHE subscriber has opened School for IL the cure of STAMMERING or STUT- TERlNG. at Wm. Germonds. in the town of Pleasant Valley, Duchess co. N. Y' From the experience he has had in curing this ai:- f1icting impeachment of the speech, he feels confident that he can affect cure in all such cases. AMASA HOJ.COMB, Jr

 This is to certify that have been afflicted with most obstinate stammerng for nearly 80 years which thought could not be correc- ted, short of miracle. After having attend ed Mr. Holcomb's Institution days, am able to speak and read with perfect facility, I would earnestly recommend any one who is afflicted in the same way, to put themselves under his care. As am persuaded that on the part of the pupil nothing is necessary, bu; strict observance of his rules to ensure a speedy recovery.

 OBADIAH B. BRIGGS.

 Clinton, (N. Y.) Jan. 13, 1897. 3i

CHA Y'S HCh Ointment,

to the insurrection and the cause of the in- surrection in Venezuela. We are indebt-

 cd to friend whose personal acquaintance

 in that country has enabled him to give us

 facts as ascertained on the spot relative to

 the immediate cause of the recent meas

 ures and movements of Gen. PacZ. First.

 The persons who are considered the prime

 movers of this faction, are said to be Dr..

 Pena, Col. Carabana, and one other per-

 son whose name is not recollected. These

 are the advisers of Gen. Paez aud Gen.

 Merino, but Gen. Paez in particular, as

 Chief in command. Dr. Pena is said to

 be a man of the greatest talents, who has

 figured as such in intrigue during the whole

 of the Revolution. He held civil office

 high in the government, (believed first

 Judge in the high court of Bogota, and

 was implicated or impeached for some mis-

 confederation which he was entrusted

 with about 50O,OOO dollars at Bogota or

 Carthagena, to deliver at Caracas, by the

 Government of Colombia, being for the benefit of the landholders, loan for them, or a part of one of the Engliah loans, ap- propriated for the planters on bond and mortgage-Pena receipted for the amount in dollars. There is a difference in the value of currency, or cut money, at Car thagena and Bogota, from the value at La Guayra and Caracas; at the former $l6 of cut money is equal to doubloon, and at the latter SIS to the doubloon. Pena made disposition of his cut money and invested the amount in doubloons, and on his arrival at Caracas, he answered the receipt of so many dollars, in doubloons at SIS, thereby realizing 12 12 per cent nett profit. His conduct was made sub- ject of severe remark in the public news papers, and he replied, II receipted for so many dollars; ! have paid the same a. mount of dollars, ,and have made certain sum of money by the operation; and if this is crime go to Bogota where learnt my vices, for remedy" He was under arrest at the time of the Paez insurrec- ton.

 Pena stated to friend of the writer at Caracas, that his country had disgraced him, had robbed him of his honor, and he should do all in his power to ruin the gov- 

 Caraband.-Of this man, who held al Colonel's commission, the writer knows

 little, except that he is represented as pos- sessing fine talents, and was educated in Europe. Pena and Carabana are the prin- cipal advisers of Paez.

 MorinO.-This man who holds the of ice of second Military Chief under Paez, las been it is believed a long time dissat- sGed with the rulers of Bogota. He is represented as a turbulent spirit, destitute ] of principle, and of flimited talents, but one who was disappointed at not receiving such appointments from the government of Bogota, as were in his opinion equal to lis merits.

 Pacz.-A great deal has been said of his man, and frequently he has been ter ned negro. The writer has frequently 'een him. He is about five feet and seven nches in height,e stout muscular frame, asd very keen black eye. His complex ion is dark (though not darker than many of our countrymen) but nothing of the ne- gro he is fairly termed Creole of the country. Paez is said to be an illiterate man, and until the recent events in Vene- zuela was considered an honest man and 1 true patriot. But in consequence of his arrest, owing to his conduct relative to the citizens and militia, it is believed he be- came exasperated against the general gov ernment. Although he took the civil pow CT into his own hands, yet it was believed the state of the country justified it. That Gen. Paez at the time of his arrest was much irritated, and that his passions were then worked upon by Pena and his other advisers, cannot be doubted, and has even

 been proved by his subsequent conduct in joining these people for remedy of abu-

 ses. That Paez on reflection has most

 sincerely regretted it, there is no doubt.-

 He is now placed in situation of great

 hazard. It is believed he will use his en- deavors to prevent any bloodseed, and re- tain his command until the arrival of Boli- var, when his conduct will probably be overlooked, whatever may be the fate of his advisers. Venezuela as regards the

 General Government is certainly in a more

 promising state than many suppose. Col.

 Ruiz on the east holds possession of Gu

 mana with force of 900 men. He is one

 of the Paez faction. Gen. Bermudez, who

 attacked Cumana in November, and was

 defeated, and retired to Barcelona, short

 distance west of Cumana, on the coast. is

 one of the generals of the revolution. and
COLOMBIA.

S1 1hAVs

 In England, wheat and rye straw are as carefully preserved and as economical- lv expended for fodder as hay.-Every farmer has what he calls his staw yard, where his young stock is kept wholly on straw, and this notwithstanding the disad- vantages of the climate. In England they always have what we call very open winter, the weather changeable, and the ground bare the greater part of the time. Every one has observed the greater diff culty in keeping a stock upon straw in such winter. They also feed their straw to horses, COWS and oxen' and they would as soon waste their hay as their strw; and cannot perceive why it is not as useful for Vermont farmer to make s use of his straw for fodder as for the Eng fish farmer. I heard very intelligent and successful farmer of this county remark some years since, that he could not afford to keep stock of cattle without raising grain so that he could feed them princi- pally with straw, nor could he afford to raise grain unless he kept stock of cattle to feed upon his straw. But to make the best use of straw for the feed either of cattle or horses, it has long since been found that it is necessary to cut it in some kind of machine. The Dutch from their first settlement in the Stase of New York, kept their horses on cut straw and meal, making use of very simple machine con- slsting only of a box and knife, and this was the only machine for cutting straw known in New England until within few years past. In England various machines for cutting straw have been invented and in general use, but as is the case with most of the English labor saving machines, they are too complicated and too expensive ; those now in general use cost from fifty to eighty dollars. A variety of machines fol cutting straw have been invented in New England, more simple in their construction and less expensive the most valuable O. these is Saford's Straw Cutter. Accor ding to accounts given of Straw Cutters, straw can be cut by none of them with greater facility or despatch than with this although it costs but about one third the sum that those cost.

 A late Bordeaux paper relates the fol- lowing singular occurrence in the neigh borhood of that city: An old woman wh had formerly kept hotel, avowed to he confessor that she had amassed large sur of money which she kept in her house, Soon after this confession, made at tn tribunal of penitence, she permitted al old position who had formely lived witt her to sleep in her house. About o'clock at night some one knocked loudl at her door, and asked in pitiful voic to be admitted to her hospitality for tn night. Believing herself safe by hay ing the position in the house, the woma opened the door, when in rushed ( ma hidden by mask and armed with pistols who said, deliver me your money or will instantly kill you !'' The poor wo man at first was almost frightened to deat but gained little courage, conducted tn robber into the chamber where the post ilion was sleeping; he having heard ther coming in, hid himself behind the curtains My money is in that closet," said tn woman, at the same time showing an ol, peice or furniture almost hidden by a pill of linen. The robber, laying his pistol on the table, prepared to take possession of her riches, but the postilion who hac observed his movements with great san!

From the Middlebury Standard.

Shocking Transaction at NST-LOndOn. We learn from correspondent at New London, that on Monday night last, u quarrel took place in cellar, occupied as grocery, between a man by the name of Spencer, and two brothers by the name of Forsyth. Spencer was, or had been, sailor. After he left the cellar, the two Forsyths offered the fireman of the steam boat, Long Branch, who was present, three dollars if he would Ego and beat the d-d rascal" while they were to stand by with clubs, and knock the first man down who attempted to interfere The frman clo- sed with the proposal, followed Spencer, and knocked him down in the street. Af- ter some struggle, Spencer succeeded in getting to the Hole-n-the-Wal public house, though not until he had received a severe foging. The fireman afterwards went to Spencer, expressed his sorrow for what he had done, and by way of settle ment paid him the three dollars received from the Forsyth, and took his receipt in full for the Aoging. Spencer afterwards died, and on Saturday the fireman and two Forsyths were lodged in gaol to await their trial. The same day, Saturday the wife of Spencer, being somewhat intoxica- ted met Mrs Barns, who was no friend of hers. A quarrel ensued, severe blows were interchanged, and Mrs. went off severely pounded. Yesterday morning she died; and the deceased Spencer's widow was lodged in prison with those who had compassed tbn death of her husband-a!l to meet their trials together.

THE Subscriber will sell at Public Auc- 1 tion on the premises at 9 o'clock P M. of January 27th, 1927, all the right or title which is invested in him by virtue of Deed of Assignment given to him by Jacob Com nlng of Washington in or to the Land and Buildings, now occupied by said Comming, called his homestead.-Terms of payment very favourable.-All persons having claims against said Comming, are requested to pre- sent them to the subscriber on or before said s7th day of January 1927; if they expect to receive any benefit from the avails of his prop erty agreeable to assignment.

 CHARLES A. HUDSON, Assignee.

 Dated, Washington, Dec. 28, 1926. 50

full articles.headline: English notiees of 1lnleriean Agrieultuce.
full articles.article:
English notices Cf Anleriedn AgriCulturc

 The New England Farmer gives the following extracts from London, an Eng fish writer.

 An American laborer is most expert al the use of the axe and the scythe; the spade he handles in very awkward man. ner. and has no ideas of banking, hedging, clipping, or cutting hedges, and many oth- CT operations known to every laborer m a hiohlv cultivated and enclosed country like Britain. Rut the versatility ot talents of an American laborer amply compensatcS for his inexperieuce ill these operations, and is more useful in his circumstances In handling the saw, the hammer, and even the trowel, the British laborer has no chance with him. Most of them can build > a house, mend plough or wagon, and C. ven the harness, aud kill and dress sheep and pigs.

 As a country for British farmer to em- igrate to, we consider the United States as superior to every other, in many respects First on account of its form ofgovernment: by which property is secure, personal lib- erty greater than any where else, consist GnlV WlLn puDlIC SdIOlJ , "n~ Oo'' A"'AA'N"A" ed at less expence than under any govern ment in the world. Secondly, on account of the stock of people being generally British, and speaking the same language. The only objection we have to America is the climate, the long and severe winter, and the rapid and hot spring and summer. Equally good land, and nearly as cheap, may be had in the south of Russia and in Poland, as in America; but who that knows any thing of the governments of tIJose countries, or even of Germany and France, would voluntarily put themselves in their power while the United States are accessible Who would live in country of tyrsnnic nobles, often very deficient of moral principal and ofa peasantry little better than hogs, and not so we'll fed and lodged as that animal is in England Who would live in country of passports, of spies, and swarming with beggarly gentry!

full articles.headline: STAMMERING.
full articles.article:
NHE subscriber has opened School for IL the cure of STAMMERING or STUT- TERlNG. at Wm. Germonds. in the town of Pleasant Valley, Duchess co. N. Y' From the experience he has had in curing this ai:- f1icting impeachment of the speech, he feels confident that he can affect cure in all such cases. AMASA HOJ.COMB, Jr

 This is to certify that have been afflicted with most obstinate stammerng for nearly 80 years which thought could not be correc- ted, short of miracle. After having attend ed Mr. Holcomb's Institution days, am able to speak and read with perfect facility, I would earnestly recommend any one who is afflicted in the same way, to put themselves under his care. As am persuaded that on the part of the pupil nothing is necessary, bu; strict observance of his rules to ensure a speedy recovery.

 OBADIAH B. BRIGGS.

 Clinton, (N. Y.) Jan. 13, 1897. 3i

full articles.headline:
MASONIC NOTICE

CALEB MORGAN'S ESTATE.
full articles.article:
CALEB MORGAN'S ESTATE. VNHE Hon. Court of Probate for the Dis N trict of New Milford has limited and al- lowed six months from the date hereof fer the Creditors to the estate of

 CALEB MORGAN,

 late of Kent in said district deceased, repre- sented insolvent to exhibit their claims thereto, and has appointed Alpheus Fuller and John M. Raymond Commissioners to receive and examine said claims certified by MATTEL PERRY, Clerk. The subscribers give notice that they shall meet at the late dwelling house of the said deceased in said Kent on the first Mondays of March and Julynext at 10 o'clock in the fore noon on each of said days for the purpose of attending on the business of said appointment.

 ALPHEUS FULLER, ] COmnis-

 JOHN M. RAYMOND, { sioners. 20 Kent, Jan. 8, 1927. S1 All persons indebted to said estate are re- quested to make immediate payment to

 MATTEL P. PERRY, Adnin'r

November 21, 1926.

CTAGES leave Litchfeld for New Haven S daily, Sundays excepted.) Mail Stage leaves Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, al o'clock in the morning precisely intersects the Mail Coach at N. Haven, so that passen- gers arrive in New-York next morning at 6 o'clock.

 The Accommodation or Steamboat Line leaves Litchfeld, Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays, at II o'clock. on arrival of the AL bany Stage, and arrives in N. Haven at o. clock Same evening, and in N. York next eve ming by Steam Boat.

 For Seats in the above Lines, apply to J PARKS, agent and proprietor.

 Litchfeld, Dec. 80, 826. q9

On taking of the mask. the robber was discovered to be no o,ber than the Confessor to whom the good woman had told her secret The postilioh immediately proceeded to the Mayors and gave himself up until the af- fair can be investigated. We wait for further particulars, says the paper, before we name the conleSsor, and the place where this terrible drama was acted.-

full articles.headline: COLOMBIA.
full articles.article:
to the insurrection and the cause of the in- surrection in Venezuela. We are indebt-

 cd to friend whose personal acquaintance

 in that country has enabled him to give us

 facts as ascertained on the spot relative to

 the immediate cause of the recent meas

 ures and movements of Gen. PacZ. First.

 The persons who are considered the prime

 movers of this faction, are said to be Dr..

 Pena, Col. Carabana, and one other per-

 son whose name is not recollected. These

 are the advisers of Gen. Paez aud Gen.

 Merino, but Gen. Paez in particular, as

 Chief in command. Dr. Pena is said to

 be a man of the greatest talents, who has

 figured as such in intrigue during the whole

 of the Revolution. He held civil office

 high in the government, (believed first

 Judge in the high court of Bogota, and

 was implicated or impeached for some mis-

 confederation which he was entrusted

 with about 50O,OOO dollars at Bogota or

 Carthagena, to deliver at Caracas, by the

 Government of Colombia, being for the benefit of the landholders, loan for them, or a part of one of the Engliah loans, ap- propriated for the planters on bond and mortgage-Pena receipted for the amount in dollars. There is a difference in the value of currency, or cut money, at Car thagena and Bogota, from the value at La Guayra and Caracas; at the former $l6 of cut money is equal to doubloon, and at the latter SIS to the doubloon. Pena made disposition of his cut money and invested the amount in doubloons, and on his arrival at Caracas, he answered the receipt of so many dollars, in doubloons at SIS, thereby realizing 12 12 per cent nett profit. His conduct was made sub- ject of severe remark in the public news papers, and he replied, II receipted for so many dollars; ! have paid the same a. mount of dollars, ,and have made certain sum of money by the operation; and if this is crime go to Bogota where learnt my vices, for remedy" He was under arrest at the time of the Paez insurrec- ton.

 Pena stated to friend of the writer at Caracas, that his country had disgraced him, had robbed him of his honor, and he should do all in his power to ruin the gov- 

 Caraband.-Of this man, who held al Colonel's commission, the writer knows

 little, except that he is represented as pos- sessing fine talents, and was educated in Europe. Pena and Carabana are the prin- cipal advisers of Paez.

 MorinO.-This man who holds the of ice of second Military Chief under Paez, las been it is believed a long time dissat- sGed with the rulers of Bogota. He is represented as a turbulent spirit, destitute ] of principle, and of flimited talents, but one who was disappointed at not receiving such appointments from the government of Bogota, as were in his opinion equal to lis merits.

 Pacz.-A great deal has been said of his man, and frequently he has been ter ned negro. The writer has frequently 'een him. He is about five feet and seven nches in height,e stout muscular frame, asd very keen black eye. His complex ion is dark (though not darker than many of our countrymen) but nothing of the ne- gro he is fairly termed Creole of the country. Paez is said to be an illiterate man, and until the recent events in Vene- zuela was considered an honest man and 1 true patriot. But in consequence of his arrest, owing to his conduct relative to the citizens and militia, it is believed he be- came exasperated against the general gov ernment. Although he took the civil pow CT into his own hands, yet it was believed the state of the country justified it. That Gen. Paez at the time of his arrest was much irritated, and that his passions were then worked upon by Pena and his other advisers, cannot be doubted, and has even

 been proved by his subsequent conduct in joining these people for remedy of abu-

 ses. That Paez on reflection has most

 sincerely regretted it, there is no doubt.-

 He is now placed in situation of great

 hazard. It is believed he will use his en- deavors to prevent any bloodseed, and re- tain his command until the arrival of Boli- var, when his conduct will probably be overlooked, whatever may be the fate of his advisers. Venezuela as regards the

 General Government is certainly in a more

 promising state than many suppose. Col.

 Ruiz on the east holds possession of Gu

 mana with force of 900 men. He is one

 of the Paez faction. Gen. Bermudez, who

 attacked Cumana in November, and was

 defeated, and retired to Barcelona, short

 distance west of Cumana, on the coast. is

 one of the generals of the revolution. and

full articles.headline:
From the Middlebury Standard.

 STRAW.
full articles.article:
S1 1hAVs

 In England, wheat and rye straw are as carefully preserved and as economical- lv expended for fodder as hay.-Every farmer has what he calls his staw yard, where his young stock is kept wholly on straw, and this notwithstanding the disad- vantages of the climate. In England they always have what we call very open winter, the weather changeable, and the ground bare the greater part of the time. Every one has observed the greater diff culty in keeping a stock upon straw in such winter. They also feed their straw to horses, COWS and oxen' and they would as soon waste their hay as their strw; and cannot perceive why it is not as useful for Vermont farmer to make s use of his straw for fodder as for the Eng fish farmer. I heard very intelligent and successful farmer of this county remark some years since, that he could not afford to keep stock of cattle without raising grain so that he could feed them princi- pally with straw, nor could he afford to raise grain unless he kept stock of cattle to feed upon his straw. But to make the best use of straw for the feed either of cattle or horses, it has long since been found that it is necessary to cut it in some kind of machine. The Dutch from their first settlement in the Stase of New York, kept their horses on cut straw and meal, making use of very simple machine con- slsting only of a box and knife, and this was the only machine for cutting straw known in New England until within few years past. In England various machines for cutting straw have been invented and in general use, but as is the case with most of the English labor saving machines, they are too complicated and too expensive ; those now in general use cost from fifty to eighty dollars. A variety of machines fol cutting straw have been invented in New England, more simple in their construction and less expensive the most valuable O. these is Saford's Straw Cutter. Accor ding to accounts given of Straw Cutters, straw can be cut by none of them with greater facility or despatch than with this although it costs but about one third the sum that those cost.

 A late Bordeaux paper relates the fol- lowing singular occurrence in the neigh borhood of that city: An old woman wh had formerly kept hotel, avowed to he confessor that she had amassed large sur of money which she kept in her house, Soon after this confession, made at tn tribunal of penitence, she permitted al old position who had formely lived witt her to sleep in her house. About o'clock at night some one knocked loudl at her door, and asked in pitiful voic to be admitted to her hospitality for tn night. Believing herself safe by hay ing the position in the house, the woma opened the door, when in rushed ( ma hidden by mask and armed with pistols who said, deliver me your money or will instantly kill you !'' The poor wo man at first was almost frightened to deat but gained little courage, conducted tn robber into the chamber where the post ilion was sleeping; he having heard ther coming in, hid himself behind the curtains My money is in that closet," said tn woman, at the same time showing an ol, peice or furniture almost hidden by a pill of linen. The robber, laying his pistol on the table, prepared to take possession of her riches, but the postilion who hac observed his movements with great san!
